slides.title: Writing Assignment Rules
slides.ocrText: Writing Assignment Rules

slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

• Describe the ClaimCenter assignment model
• Assign entities to groups and users

slides.title: What can be assigned?
slides.originalNotes:
What can be assigned?
ClaimCenter can automatically assign entities to users using assignment rules. In the base configuration, there are six types of entities that can be assigned: Claims, Exposures, Matters, Subrogations, Service Requests, and Activities. It is possible to configure ClaimCenter to assign other entity types.

Recall that users are members of groups. An entity is assigned first to agroup, and then to a user within that group.
slides.notes:

slides.title: Queues
slides.originalNotes:
Queues
A queue is a place where activities wait to be assigned to a user. A queue is associated with a group.
A queue defined on a parent group can be made visible to all child groups so that users of the parent and child groups can all access activities on the queue. Group members with the necessary permissions can assign activities from the queue to themselves or to other users.
slides.notes:
Queues
A queue is a place where activities wait to be assigned to a user. A queue is associated with a group.
A queue defined on a parent group can be made visible to all child groups so that users of the parent and child groups can all access activities on the queue. Group members with the necessary permissions can assign activities from the queue to themselves or to other users.
slides.ocrText:
| Queues G

• Are places for unassigned activities to “wait” until they are assigned
• Every group in the organization can have one or more associated queues

* Queues can be “shared” by creating the queue on a parent group and making it visible to all
child groups

• Activities assigned to the group, but not to a specific user, can be placed in the
queue

• Group supervisor can assign activities from the queue to subordinates
* Group members can assign activities from the queue to themselves

• Only activities can be placed in a queue

slides.title: Assignment rule sets
slides.originalNotes:
Assignment rule sets
Entity assignment by rules can take up to two passes. This is explained in greater detail on the next slide.
slides.notes:
Assignment rule sets
Entity assignment by rules can take up to two passes. This is explained in greater detail on the next slide.
slides.ocrText:
| Assignment rule sets

• For each assignable entity there are
two rule sets:
* Global<Entity>AssignmentRules
+ Run first
+ Assign entity to group
* May assign entity to a user
• DefaultGroup<Entity>AssignmentRules

+ Run if Global rules do not assign entity toa
user

+ Assign entity to user

slides.title: Assignment flow
slides.originalNotes:
Assignment flow
When an entity is created, it might be manually assigned by the user. If it is not, then the Global <EntitY> Assignment Rules are executed automatically.
The Global <entitY> Assignment Rules have three possible outcomes:

1. One of the rules assigns both a group and a user for the entity. If this occurs, then assignment of the entity is complete.

2. One of the rules assigns a group but not a user for the entity. If this occurs, then the Default Group <entitY> Assignment Rules are run for the entity to assign a user.

3. None of the rules succeed in assigning a group for the entity. If this occurs, then the object is assigned to the Default Owner for manual assignment.

The Default Group <entitY> assignment rules attempt to assign the entity to a specific user. If successful, then the assignment of the entity is complete.

If it not successful, the Default Group rules may assign the entityto a new group, in which case the Default Group <entitY> Assignment Rules run again for that group. If no new group is assigned, and no user is assigned, then the entity is assigned to the group supervisor for the assigned group, for manual assignment
slides.notes:
Assignment flow
When an entity is created, it might be manually assigned by the user. If it is not, then the Global <EntitY> Assignment Rules are executed automatically.
The Global <entitY> Assignment Rules have three possible outcomes:

1. One of the rules assigns both a group and a user for the entity. If this occurs, then assignment of the entity is complete.

2. One of the rules assigns a group but not a user for the entity. If this occurs, then the Default Group <entitY> Assignment Rules are run for the entity to assign a user.

3. None of the rules succeed in assigning a group for the entity. If this occurs, then the object is assigned to the Default Owner for manual assignment.

The Default Group <entitY> assignment rules attempt to assign the entity to a specific user. If successful, then the assignment of the entity is complete.

If it not successful, the Default Group rules may assign the entityto a new group, in which case the Default Group <entitY> Assignment Rules run again for that group. If no new group is assigned, and no user is assigned, then the entity is assigned to the group supervisor for the assigned group, for manual assignment

slides.title: Default owner assignment
slides.originalNotes:
Default owner assignment
After global assignment rules have been executed, the assignment engine checks to see if the entity was assigned to a group. If the entity has not been assigned to a group, then it is assigned to a "dummy" user called Default Owner and the root group of the hierarchy. (If the entity was assigned to a group, then assignment proceeds as normal.)

The "Default Owner" is a dummy user used for entities which "fail" group assignment- You cannot lo on as the Default Owner, and there is typically extra
overhead in identifying entities assigned to Default Owner and reassigning them to a real user. Assignment to the Default Owner indicates flaws in the assignment rule logic that must be corrected. Routine monitoring should be performed to check for objects assigned to the Default Owner, and these
 should be manually assigned to a group and user. The recommended best practice is to have a default assignment rule at the bottom of every Global rule set, which assigns any uncaught entities to a group that is tasked to handle this situation.

Under no circumstances should a rule assign an entity directly to the Default Owner. *Technically, the entity will. only be assigned to the Default Owner if this is a new assignment- If this is are assignment, then group assignment failure will result in the entity reverting to the current owner.
slides.notes:
Default owner assignment
After global assignment rules have been executed, the assignment engine checks to see if the entity was assigned to a group. If the entity has not been assigned to a group, then it is assigned to a "dummy" user called Default Owner and the root group of the hierarchy. (If the entity was assigned to a group, then assignment proceeds as normal.)

The "Default Owner" is a dummy user used for entities which "fail" group assignment- You cannot lo on as the Default Owner, and there is typically extra
overhead in identifying entities assigned to Default Owner and reassigning them to a real user. Assignment to the Default Owner indicates flaws in the assignment rule logic that must be corrected. Routine monitoring should be performed to check for objects assigned to the Default Owner, and these
 should be manually assigned to a group and user. The recommended best practice is to have a default assignment rule at the bottom of every Global rule set, which assigns any uncaught entities to a group that is tasked to handle this situation.

Under no circumstances should a rule assign an entity directly to the Default Owner. *Technically, the entity will. only be assigned to the Default Owner if this is a new assignment- If this is are assignment, then group assignment failure will result in the entity reverting to the current owner.

slides.title: CCAssignable delegate (1 of 2)
slides.originalNotes:
CCAssignabIe delegate (1 of 2)
Implementing the CCAssignable delegate is what makes an entity assignable. Thus, if you need to make some additional entity assignable, you must

Implement the CCAssignable delegate for that entity

Create assignment rule sets (both Global and Default Group) for that entity

Implement rules in those rule sets

 Test, test, test!

CurrentAssignment is a method that permits assigning not only anowner, but other individuals with roles on an entity. These roles are discussed in the lesson on Configuring Claim Contacts.
slides.notes:
CCAssignabIe delegate (1 of 2)
Implementing the CCAssignable delegate is what makes an entity assignable. Thus, if you need to make some additional entity assignable, you must

CurrentAssignment is a method that permits assigning not only anowner, but other individuals with roles on an entity. These roles are discussed in the lesson on Configuring Claim Contacts.

slides.originalNotes:
CCAssignabIe delegate (2 of 2)
The CurrentAssignment method is only valid within the scope of the Assignment Rules; assignment done elsewhere cannot use CurrentAssignment.

slides.title: Assignment in the UI
slides.originalNotes:
Assignment in the UI
In some screens, such as at the end of the FNOL Wizard, claim search results, Team screen, Desktop screens, and the Actions menu, you can manually assig entities. You can use automated assignment, choose from a list, or search for a group or user.

Automated assignment works as described in this lesson.

The list of "Suggested Assignees“ includes yourself, the current claimlexposure owner, and everyone in your group to whom the entity can be assigned. In the screenshot, Sue Smith is the manager of the Autol — TeamA team, so all its members are listed.
slides.notes:

slides.title: Assignment methods
slides.originalNotes:
Assignment methods
CurrentAssignment is a property of an entity that comes from the CCAssignable delegate. The methods that perform assignment are methods of CurrentAssignment. There are many of these methods, each of which has unique characteristics. An assignment method returns a Boolean value. The reason this is useful appears on the next slide.
slides.notes:
Assignment methods
CurrentAssignment is a property of an entity that comes from the CCAssignable delegate. The methods that perform assignment are methods of CurrentAssignment. There are many of these methods, each of which has unique characteristics. An assignment method returns a Boolean value. The reason this is useful appears on the next slide.
slides.ocrText:
| Assignment methods

• Assign entities to groups and users using provided methods
• Are provided by CurrentAssignment

« For example,
activity.CurrentAssignment.assignGroup (activity.Claim.AssignedGroup)
attempts to assign an activity to a group.

• Return a Boolean value
* True if assignment was successful

• False if appropriate group/user could not be assigned by this rule

slides.title: actions.exit() method
slides.originalNotes:
actions.exit() method
Once you have assigned an object to its final group, there is no reason to continue in the ruleset. Furthermore, there is some risk that a rule further down in the list will reassign your object to another group in a way that you do not want. Therefore, it is important to execute the actions-exit() method as soon as the object has an appropriate group assignment.

By wrapping the assignment method inside the parentheses of an if clause, you will exit the ruleset if and only if theassignment is successful. It is best practice to use this approach for every single assignment method in your assignment rulesets.
slides.notes:
actions.exit() method
Once you have assigned an object to its final group, there is no reason to continue in the ruleset. Furthermore, there is some risk that a rule further down in the list will reassign your object to another group in a way that you do not want. Therefore, it is important to execute the actions-exit() method as soon as the object has an appropriate group assignment.

By wrapping the assignment method inside the parentheses of an if clause, you will exit the ruleset if and only if theassignment is successful. It is best practice to use this approach for every single assignment method in your assignment rulesets.
slides.ocrText:
| actions.exit() method

Ends the execution of the rule set
• Should be executed when assignment is successful:
if (assignMethod) {

actions.exit()

ACTION (activity entity.Activity, actions : gw.rules.Action) :
var assignedGroup = activity.Claim.AssignedGroup

if (activity.CurrentAssignment.assign(assignedGroup, assignedGroup.Supervisor)) {
actions.exit ()

}
END

slides.title: Commonly-used assignment methods
slides.originalNotes:
Commonly-used assignment methods
CCAssignable's assign() and assignx() methods provide a number of possible strategies for assigning an object. There are more methods than are shown here, but these are the methods you will use most of the time. These, and all the other methods, are defined in more detail in the ClaimCenter Rules Guide.

In the table, some group variables are marked with a * These variables may be set to null in calling the method.

slides.title: Dynamic assignment
slides.originalNotes:
Dynamic assignment
Dynamic assignment allows you to define a strategy different from those provided in the base configuration The details of this are complex and beyond the scope of this lesson; they may be found in the Rules Guide of the ClaimCenter product documentation.
slides.notes:
Dynamic assignment
Dynamic assignment allows you to define a strategy different from those provided in the base configuration The details of this are complex and beyond the scope of this lesson; they may be found in the Rules Guide of the ClaimCenter product documentation.
slides.ocrText:
| Dynamic assignment

• Is an advanced topic
* Offers two methods:
* assignGroupDynamically(dynamicGroupAssignmentStrategy)
* assignUserDynamically(dynamicUserAssignmentStrategy)
* The argument of these methods must implement an interface, respectively
* DynamicGroupAssignmentStrategy

+ DynamicUserAssignmentStrategy
